items.content_html:
Recently I wondered if I was done with sports. Then I started playing NCAA Football 13 again. Now most of my YouTube time is spent watching coaches break down the air raid offense so that I can turn LA Tech into the dynasty it deserves.

Also, I’m loving me some 4-2-5 defense.

Also, I'm loving me some 4-2-5 defense.

items.content_html: I was sitting in the Garage Cafe, listening to some tunes on my iPad, when my neighbor decided to mow his back yard. I beamed my displeasure over the fence, in his direction, and he stopped and went back inside. I might have telepathy, y’all.

items.content_html:
I can handle if someone dislikes my writing, but there are two criticisms I try to avoid:

  1. Jake’s writing wasn’t clear; or
  2. Man, Jake just went on and on and on and on and on.

That said, I’ve been trying to let loose with my stories to give them room to grow. This morning, I finished what may be the longest story I’ve ever written, and I can’t help asking myself how the hell it got out of control.
items.content_text:
I can handle if someone dislikes my writing, but there are two criticisms I try to avoid:

1. Jake's writing wasn't clear; or
2. Man, Jake just went on and on and on and on and on.

That said, I've been trying to let loose with my stories to give them room to grow. This morning, I finished what may be the longest story I've ever written, and I can't help asking myself how the hell it got out of control.

items.content_html: Earlier today I finished re-reading Stephen King’s On Writing, and while I doubt King cares one bit about my opinion, I owe him an apology. I’ve criticized On Writing as being heavy on memoir and light on writing tips, but I now realize how wrong I was.

This morning I learned that “spicket” is not a real word. The word I was looking for is “spigot.”

Despite growing up in the sticks, I’ve never thought of myself as a country boy, but this is a reminder that we’re all shaped by where we were raised.

items.content_html: I prefer not to read books by the same author back to back, but after re-reading Albert Camus’s The Stranger, I couldn’t resist the urge to check out The Plague, which I’ll start tonight. Though the book likely should have been on my 2020 list, it still feels timely in 2021.
items.content_text: I prefer not to read books by the same author back to back, but after re-reading Albert Camus's *The Stranger*, I couldn't resist the urge to check out *The Plague*, which I'll start tonight. Though the book likely should have been on my 2020 list, it still feels timely in 2021.

items.content_html:
Some things I’m using to push me toward finishing a novel/novella:

  1. Write 500 words a day. Stop once I’ve hit my goal.
  2. Pick up wherever yesterday’s writing left off. No deleting previous days’ efforts.

I’m pretty sure what I have so far is horrible, but I’m reminding myself that the point is to complete a rough draft. It’s easier to rewrite and edit when you actually have something to work with. Perfection is a pointless goal, and great writing is iterative.
items.content_text:
Some things I'm using to push me toward finishing a novel/novella:

1. Write 500 words a day. Stop once I've hit my goal.
2. Pick up wherever yesterday's writing left off. No deleting previous days' efforts.

I'm pretty sure what I have so far is horrible, but I'm reminding myself that the point is to complete a rough draft. It's easier to rewrite and edit when you actually have something to work with. Perfection is a pointless goal, and great writing is iterative.

items.content_html:
My first live music spiritual experience was courtesy of Radiohead in 2008, shortly after I had moved to Texas. Music had been my drug of choice since I was a teenager, and experiencing three members playing the same heavy beat during the beginning of “There, There” reached some primal part of me that had never been touched before.

The song remains my favorite Radiohead tune and has some of my favorite lines:

Just ‘cause you feel it

Doesn’t mean it’s there

How fallible we are, how poor our judgment…

There’s always a siren

Singing you to shipwreck

So many promises sound so pretty yet lead only to disaster…

We are accidents

Waiting to happen

Always reminds me of humanity’s imperfect nature…

I don’t know why this song and that experience are in my head right now, and I don’t know why I feel compelled to write about them in this messy way, but I do and so I am.
items.content_text:
My first live music spiritual experience was courtesy of Radiohead [in 2008](https://www.concertarchives.org/concerts/radiohead--34), shortly after I had moved to Texas.  Music had been my drug of choice since I was a teenager, and experiencing three members playing the same heavy beat during the beginning of ["There, There"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7AQSLozK7aA) reached some primal part of me that had never been touched before.

The song remains my favorite Radiohead tune and has some of my favorite lines:

> Just 'cause you feel it 

> Doesn't mean it's there

How fallible we are, how poor our judgment...

> There's always a siren

> Singing you to shipwreck

So many promises sound so pretty yet lead only to disaster...

> We are accidents

> Waiting to happen

Always reminds me of humanity's imperfect nature...

I don't know why this song and that experience are in my head right now, and I don't know why I feel compelled to write about them in this messy way, but I do and so I am.

items.content_html:
I recently obligated myself to write at least 500 words every day. I intended to fill my obligations by writing fiction, whether vignettes or flash or stories that went beyond 500 words, but I’ve instead filled them with philosophical rants.

I’m fourteen years old again.
items.content_text:
I recently obligated myself to write at least 500 words every day. I intended to fill my obligations by writing fiction, whether vignettes or flash or stories that went beyond 500 words, but I've instead filled them with philosophical rants.

I'm [fourteen years old](https://www.reddit.com/r/im14andthisisdeep/) again.

items.content_html:
Epictetus has been dropping some fire in the last couple entries of The Daily Stoic:

4.10

It isn’t events themselves that disturb people, but only their judgments about them.

4.11

Throw out your conceited opinions, for it is impossible for a person to begin to learn what he thinks he already knows.
items.content_text:

items.content_html:
This week, inspired by the Shuffle plugin for Obsidian, I made a goal to write 500 words every day. Since making this goal, I have written every day but have hit 500 words only once–my first day, when I wrote two prompts.

The problem is that if I have specific goals (such as including three certain words in a story), I focus only on those requirements and try to squeeze them in as quickly as possible, neglecting to write an actual story.
items.content_text:
This week, inspired by the [Shuffle plugin for Obsidian](http://jakelacaze.com/2021/04/06/i-havent-had.html), I made a goal to write 500 words every day. Since making this goal, I have written every day but have hit 500 words only once--my first day, when I wrote two prompts. 

The problem is that if I have specific goals (such as including three certain words in a story), I focus only on those requirements and try to squeeze them in as quickly as possible, neglecting to write *an actual story*.

items.content_html: Philip K. Dick’s The Man in the High Castle is the first book I’ve given up on this year. I would have thought a book that rewrites history so that the Axis powers win World War II would be much more interesting by the time I was a third of the way through it.
items.content_text: Philip K. Dick's *The Man in the High Castle* is the first book I've given up on this year. I would have thought a book that rewrites history so that the Axis powers win World War II would be much more interesting by the time I was a third of the way through it.

items.content_html:
I was planning to release a short story collection on Kindle, but now I’m thinking about putting it together in iA writer and releasing it as an EPUB.

I don’t have much of a digital presence and I’m not going to put a marketing strategy behind it. The real value will come from the experience of putting the collection together. And if some people read it and I get some exposure, that’ll be pure bonus.

items.content_text: Someone recently shared a story about how he had to dodge the clothesline whenever he backed out to leave his grandmother's house and then when he went back to her place after she'd died, he accommodated for the clothesline even though it was no longer there.

items.content_html:
I’ve been in a writing funk lately. This morning I forced myself to resume a certain short story, which took a slight turn and excited me and now has the writer wheels in my brain turning again.

I’m sure there’s a moral somewhere in this anecdote.
items.content_text:

I'm sure there's a moral somewhere in this anecdote.

items.content_html: I’m ready for the return of spring. I need to take advantage of the weather and longer days by playing more disc golf.

items.content_html:
A couple years ago, my son picked up this bookmark and said, “It’s you, Daddy,” alerting me that I am literally his model for what it means to be a man.

No pressure, son. No pressure.

items.content_html:
Our last visit to Fry’s, in January 2020. I had never before been sad to see a store withering away.

I wasted so much money here and bought my son so many 50-cent ninja men from the gumball-style machines at the front of the store.

RIP in peace, Fry’s
items.content_text: Our last visit to Fry's, in January 2020. I had never before been sad to see a store withering away. I wasted so much money here and bought my son so many 50-cent ninja men from the gumball-style machines at the front of the store. [RIP in peace](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/frys-electronics-chain-closing/), Fry's

items.content_html: Reading Ernest Hemingway’s In Our Time makes me realize that I don’t dislike Hemingway–I dislike Hemingway’s novels. His short stories are top notch.
items.content_text: Reading Ernest Hemingway's *In Our Time* makes me realize that I don't dislike Hemingway--I dislike Hemingway's novels. His short stories are top notch.

items.content_html:
2 takeaways from 2020 and beyond:

  1. When criticizing a system, don’t compare it to Utopia. Compare it to absolute disaster, since that is far likelier than Utopia.

  2. Functioning systems are not a given; they are blessings which can be easily derailed.
items.content_text:
2 takeaways from 2020 and beyond:

1. When criticizing a system, don't compare it to Utopia. Compare it to absolute disaster, since that is far likelier than Utopia.

2. Functioning systems are not a given; they are blessings which can be easily derailed.

items.content_html: Today I’m thinking about the time a group of us were at Cafe Brazil and the waiter said, “Happy Valentine’s Day, y’all,” as he dropped off the check and turned to walk away and it was such a strange encounter.

items.content_html:
Journaling doesn’t work for me; it ends up a mundane retelling of the day’s events with no flavor.

For last night’s entry, I took a real event from the day and fictionalized it a bit for a vignette/short story. I might have found a new journaling practice.
items.content_text:
Journaling doesn't work for me; it ends up a mundane retelling of the day's events with no flavor.

For last night's entry, I took a real event from the day and fictionalized it a bit for a vignette/short story. I might have found a new journaling practice.

items.content_html: Last night I prepped the John Wick trilogy for my Plex server, and now I’m itching to rewatch the original. I love the simplicity of John Wick and how the movie knows what it is and stays in its lane.
items.content_text: Last night I prepped the John Wick trilogy for my Plex server, and now I'm itching to rewatch the original. I love the simplicity of *John Wick* and how the movie knows what it is and stays in its lane.

items.content_html: This morning I finished Play It As It Lays, the first Joan Didion fiction I’ve read. My biggest problem with Didion is that it took me so long to check her out.
items.content_text: This morning I finished *Play It As It Lays*, the first Joan Didion fiction I've read. My biggest problem with Didion is that it took me so long to check her out.

items.content_html:
Going through the Micro Monday archives, I recently listened to #83, in which @jeremycherfas and @jean discuss Italian food, which inspired me to make stuffed shells tonight.

So my wife now approves of micro.blog even though she doesn’t really know what it is.
items.content_text:
Going through the Micro Monday archives, I recently listened to #83, in which [@jeremycherfas](https://micro.blog/jeremycherfas) and [@jean](https://micro.blog/jean) [discuss Italian food](https://monday.micro.blog/2020/03/30/jeremy-cherfas-aka.html), which inspired me to make stuffed shells tonight. 

So my wife now approves of micro.blog even though she doesn't really know what it is.

From The Ringer: All Serial-Killer Movies Should Take Place in the Pre-Cellphone Era

From The Ringer: [All Serial-Killer Movies Should Take Place in the Pre-Cellphone Era](https://www.theringer.com/movies/2021/2/3/22263279/the-little-things-se7en-silence-of-the-lambs-serial-killer-movies-pre-cell-phones)

items.content_html: One of the most refreshing things about micro.blog: I haven’t seen any gifs or memes. Not that I’m against them completely, but after a few weeks on micro.blog, it’s obvious just how prevalent memes and gifs are on social media in general.
items.content_text: One of the most refreshing things about micro.blog: I haven't seen any gifs or memes. Not that I'm against them completely, but after a few weeks on micro.blog, it's obvious just how prevalent memes and gifs are on social media in general.

items.content_html:
Confession: I once wrote an instruction manual for using a chimney starter for a technical writing class, but I almost always have problems starting my fire with a chimney starter.

I am a fraud.
items.content_text:
Confession: I once wrote [an instruction manual for using a chimney starter](https://jakelacaze.micro.blog/uploads/2021/c4b7cb86bd.pdf) for a technical writing class, but I almost always have problems starting my fire with a chimney starter. 

I am a fraud.
